entry.content:
The Problem

The problem asks us to find the maximum number of consecutive 1s in a binary array. You know, like if you have something like this:

[1, 1, 0, 1, 1, 1]

The maximum consecutive ones here is 3, right? Simple enough, that‚Äôs how we roll.

So, here‚Äôs the actual problem statement from LeetCode:

Given a binary array nums, return the maximum number of consecutive 1s in the array.

My Solution

Here‚Äôs a straightforward solution I came up with while deep in the zone (you know what I mean). I‚Äôve written it in Java, but if you‚Äôre a Python aficionado or something else, you‚Äôll get the gist!

class Solution {
    public int findMaxConsecutiveOnes(int[] nums) {
        int fc = 0;  // This is for the final count
        int lc = 0;  // This is for the current count
        
        for (int i = 0; i < nums.length; i++) {
            if (nums[i] == 0) {
                lc = 0; // If it's a zero, reset the current count
            } else {
                lc++; // Otherwise, just increment the current count
            }
            fc = Math.max(lc, fc); // Update max count
        }
        return fc; // Return the max consecutive ones
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

Let‚Äôs break down the complexity a bit because that‚Äôs always a fun part, right?

  • Time Complexity: O(n), where n is the length of the array. We only loop through the array once, so it‚Äôs pretty efficient.
  • Space Complexity: O(1), since we‚Äôre using just a couple of extra variables and not any additional data structures.

Conclusion

And there you have it, folks! My very own solution to LeetCode problem 485. It‚Äôs clean, it‚Äôs neat, and hell, it works! Each time I solve one of these LeetCode problems, I feel like I‚Äôve leveled up my coding skills, even if just a smidge. It‚Äôll certainly make my day job a bit easier, I hope!

If you want to dive deeper or see examples of more coding problems, check out the following references:

  • LeetCode Problem 485
  • Good Article on Sliding Window Techniques

entry.title: Quick Cheatsheet: Remove New Lines and Empty Lines in Linux

link.title: Quick Cheatsheet: Remove New Lines and Empty Lines in Linux

entry.content:
You know how sometimes you‚Äôre knee-deep in some file, and it‚Äôs just cluttered with new lines or annoying empty lines? Yeah, that‚Äôs the kind of crap that can drive you mad. Don‚Äôt you wish there was an easy way to wipe that all away? Well, I‚Äôve got your back. Get ready to transform your files into neat little packages with just a few commands.

Removing New Lines

First off, let‚Äôs tackle those pesky new lines. Sometimes, you end up with new lines all over the place, messing up your formatting. Here‚Äôs a quick command you can run to sweep them away.

# Use this command to remove all new lines
tr -d '\n' < input.txt > output.txt

This little gem uses tr (translate or delete characters). It takes our beloved input file, targets new lines with -d '\n', and outputs a cleaned-up version in output.txt. Pretty cool, right?

But if you only want to remove trailing new lines rather than every single one, you can use sed like this:

# To trim trailing new lines only
sed '/^$/d' input.txt > output.txt

This one-liner gets rid of empty lines. The ^$ regex matches any lines that start and end with nothing (a.k.a. empty lines). The d command deletes those lines.

Removing Empty New Lines

Okay, now let‚Äôs get to that annoying issue of empty new lines, which just clutter up your file without adding any value. Here‚Äôs another handy command:

# Removing consecutive empty lines
sed '/^$/N;/^\n$/D' input.txt > output.txt

This one uses sed again, and is a bit of a magic trick. What happens here is we look for empty lines and merge them (N) with the next line, then delete (D) if both are empty. Result? You get a file that‚Äôs compact and clean!

Additional Hacks

You might want to ensure that there are no empty lines either at the start or the end of your file. Here‚Äôs a two-in-one command to handle that:

# Primary command to remove empty lines throughout the file and trim the ends
sed -i '/^$/d; /^$/N; /^\n$/D' input.txt

This -i option edits files in place. Yup, there‚Äôs no output redirection here‚Äîyour original file gets the treatment and comes out sparkling clean.

Not Just Text Files!

You don‚Äôt just have to limit this to text files, either! If you‚Äôre working with other types of files, sometimes using tr or sed can help with quick and dirty edits without needing to open a GUI editor. Just be cautious, ‚Äòcause you could mess something up if you‚Äôre not careful.

Conclusion

So there you have it, folks! A quick cheatsheet to help you out when lines get out of hand. You no longer have to deal with end-of-the-world scenarios caused by messy files. Your code will thank you, and you can keep your sanity intact whilst making your files readable again.

References

  • GNU tr
  • GNU sed
entry.summary: This article breaks down some quick commands to tidy up files in Linux by removing unwanted new lines and those pesky empty lines. Keep your files clean and readable without breaking a sweat!

entry.title: Is Bitwise & Better than Arithmetic to Determine Even or Odd? Let‚Äôs Dive In!

link.title: Is Bitwise & Better than Arithmetic to Determine Even or Odd? Let‚Äôs Dive In!

entry.content:
Hey there, fellow code wranglers! Today‚Äôs topic is a fun and slightly nerdy one. It‚Äôs about finding out if a number is even or odd using two different methods: the classic arithmetic method and the bitwise operation. Buckle up, because we‚Äôre about to venture into the depths of zeros and ones, and I might throw in a few cheeky comments along the way!

The Classic Arithmetic Check

First up, let‚Äôs talk about the good ol‚Äô arithmetic method. You know it well: we simply take a number and check if it‚Äôs divisible by 2.

Here‚Äôs how it looks in code:

def is_even_arithmetic(num):
    return num % 2 == 0

print(is_even_arithmetic(4))  # True
print(is_even_arithmetic(5))  # False

This works like a charm! You just use the modulus operator %, and boom, you can tell in a heartbeat if a number is even. The problem? Dividing by 2 can be a smidge slow. In programming, every tiny nanosecond counts, especially when you wanna squeeze those last few drops of performance out of your app.

The Bitwise Operation Magic

Now let‚Äôs pivot to the bitwise operation. Instead of playing with division, we‚Äôre gonna go low-level and use bit manipulation. In programming, specifically in languages like C, C++, or even Python, checking if a number is even can be done like this:

def is_even_bitwise(num):
    return (num & 1) == 0

print(is_even_bitwise(4))  # True
print(is_even_bitwise(5))  # False

Bam! What happens here is that we‚Äôre using the & operator to perform a bitwise AND operation. When you perform num & 1, it checks the least significant bit of the number. If it‚Äôs a 0, the number is even; if it‚Äôs a 1, it‚Äôs odd. Simple and super fast!

Why is Bitwise Better?

You might be wondering, ‚ÄúWhy the hell would I use bitwise over arithmetic?‚Äù Well, my friend, here‚Äôs the catch!

  1. Performance: Bitwise operations are generally faster than arithmetic operations. This is because bitwise operations are performed at the hardware level, and processors are built to handle these like a boss. In a world where you can have millions of calculations (hello, algorithms!), this can make a considerable difference!

  2. Memory Efficiency: Bitwise checks can also be cheaper in terms of memory, especially in lower-level programming where every byte counts.

Real World Example

Let‚Äôs throw some practical scenarios into the mix. Say you‚Äôre working on a high-performance application that crunches large datasets or performs a ton of calculations in real-time, such as game development, data science, or AI algorithms.

That‚Äôs when you notice that using a bitwise operation can shave off those precious milliseconds from each operation. When this operation is performed millions of times in a loop, it compounds, bringing tangible benefits. Here‚Äôs an example of a loop:

def count_evens(numbers):
    count = 0
    for num in numbers:
        if is_even_bitwise(num):
            count += 1
    return count

large_dataset = range(1, 1000001)  # A million numbers
print(count_evens(large_dataset))

This will run faster using the bitwise method, and in scenarios where every microsecond counts, we nerds appreciate that!

Conclusion

So, here‚Äôs the lowdown: When it comes to determining if a number is even or odd, the bitwise operation is not just a flashy trick. It‚Äôs a legitimate performance improvement in certain cases. If you‚Äôre writing code where performance matters, then using num & 1 can give you those tiny yet impactful boosts.

Now go out there and make those decisions that count‚Äîboth in coding and in life (and please, don‚Äôt forget to keep those brackets tidy!).

References

  • Bitwise Operators - MDN Web Docs
  • Understanding Bitwise Operators - GeeksforGeeks
entry.summary: This blog post explores whether using bitwise operations is superior to arithmetic checks for determining if a number is even or odd, and uncovers the reason behind it.

entry.title: LeetCode 1295: Find Numbers with Even Number of Digits

link.title: LeetCode 1295: Find Numbers with Even Number of Digits

entry.content:
So, I‚Äôve been diving into LeetCode problems day in and day out, and today I‚Äôm going to share a neat little solution for LeetCode question 1295: Find Numbers with Even Number of Digits. You know how it goes - some days you just churn out code while other days you stare at the screen like a total idiot. But hey, let‚Äôs crack on with it!

The Problem

The problem is pretty straightforward, and honestly, it‚Äôs one of those you can solve while enjoying your coffee. The goal is to find how many numbers in a given array have an even number of digits.

So, here‚Äôs the deal:

  • You‚Äôre given an integer array nums, and you have to return the count of numbers that have an even number of digits.

My Solution

Here‚Äôs the Java solution I whipped up. You can think of it as a classic counting problem, but we‚Äôre counting digits instead of things that matter‚Äîlike pizza toppings or how many bugs we have to fix.

class Solution {
    public int findNumbers(int[] nums) {
        int counter = 0; // Initialize a counter to track numbers with even digits
        for (int num : nums) {
            int digits = 0; // Variable to count the number of digits in the current number
            // Special handling for zero since it doesn't enter the loop
            if (num == 0) {
                digits = 1;
            }
            while (num > 0) { // This loop counts the digits
                num = num / 10; // Divide by 10 to drop the last digit
                digits++; // Increment digit count
            }
            if ((digits & 1) == 0) { // Check if digits are even using bitwise AND
                counter++; // Increment counter if we have an even digit number
            }
        }
        return counter; // Return the total count of even digit numbers
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

Now let‚Äôs talk complexity, because, you know, that‚Äôs the good stuff.

  • Time Complexity: O(N * D), where N is the number of elements in the nums array and D is the average number of digits in a number. This is because we potentially examine each digit in every number.

  • Space Complexity: O(1) since we only use a fixed amount of space regardless of input size. Just a couple of integers to keep track of our counts.

References

  • LeetCode Problem 1295
  • Bit Manipulation
entry.summary: In this post, I‚Äôm sharing my solution to LeetCode question 1295. Join me as I explore how to find numbers with an even number of digits in a simple and straightforward way!

entry.title: LeetCode 977: Squares of a Sorted Array Solution

link.title: LeetCode 977: Squares of a Sorted Array Solution

entry.content:
Let‚Äôs tackle LeetCode 977: Squares of a Sorted Array. Yeah, if you‚Äôve spent any time on LeetCode, you know where we‚Äôre headed with this one. It‚Äôs all about taking a sorted array of integers, squaring them, and returning them in the same sorted order. Sounds simple, right? Well, there‚Äôs always a twist with these problems.

Problem Statement

Given an integer array nums sorted in non-decreasing order, return an array of the squares of each number, also in non-decreasing order.

Example

  • Input: nums = [-4,-1,0,3,10]
  • Output: [0, 1, 9, 16, 100]

My Solution

Here‚Äôs the Java code I cooked up for this problem:

class Solution {
    public int[] sortedSquares(int[] nums) {
        int result[] = new int[nums.length];
        int left = 0;
        int right = nums.length - 1;

        for (int i = nums.length - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
            int square = 0;
            if (Math.abs(nums[left]) > Math.abs(nums[right])) {
                square = nums[left];
                left++;
            } else {
                square = nums[right];
                right--;
            }
            result[i] = square * square;
        }
        return result;
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: O(n) ‚Äî We are only making a single pass through the array.
  • Space Complexity: O(n) ‚Äî We are using a new array to hold the results.

Conclusion

And there you have it! By using a two-pointer technique, we‚Äôve managed to solve this problem in linear time. It‚Äôs efficient, neat, and gets the job done without breaking a sweat. Now, all that‚Äôs left is to keep grinding those LeetCode problems. If you enjoyed this breakdown or have any questions, feel free to drop a comment!

References

  • LeetCode Problem 977 - Squares of a Sorted Array
  • Two Pointers Technique Explained

Happy coding! üññ
entry.summary: In this post, I'm sharing my solution for LeetCode problem 977 - Squares of a Sorted Array. Let's dive into some coding magic and tackle problem-solving head-on!

entry.title: LeetCode Question 383: Ransom Note Solution Breakdown

link.title: LeetCode Question 383: Ransom Note Solution Breakdown

entry.content:
Problem Statement

The problem states:

Given two strings ransomNote and magazine, return true if you can construct the ransomNote from the magazine and false otherwise.

Each letter in the magazine can only be used once in the ransomNote.

So, if you‚Äôre wondering whether you have enough letters in the magazine to create a ransom note, this is the problem that will help you check!

My Solution

After scratching my head for a bit (and sipping on some of that sweet, sweet coffee), I came up with a solution in Java. Here‚Äôs the code I submitted:

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

class Solution {
    public boolean canConstruct(String ransomNote, String magazine) {
        Map<Character, Integer> magazineLetter = new HashMap<>();

        // Count each letter's occurrences in the magazine
        for (int i = 0; i < magazine.length(); i++) {
            char m = magazine.charAt(i);
            int currentCount = magazineLetter.getOrDefault(m, 0);
            magazineLetter.put(m, currentCount + 1);
        }

        // Check each letter in the ransom note
        for (int i = 0; i < ransomNote.length(); i++) {
            char r = ransomNote.charAt(i);
            int currentCount = magazineLetter.getOrDefault(r, 0);
            if (currentCount == 0) {
                return false; // Not enough letters
            }
            magazineLetter.put(r, currentCount - 1); // Use one letter
        }

        return true; // Successfully constructed the ransom note
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

  • Time Complexity: O(m + n), where m is the length of the magazine and n is the length of the ransomNote. We traverse both strings linearly, so this is pretty efficient.

  • Space Complexity: O(1) in terms of the character set size, since we‚Äôre only using a fixed-size HashMap for the alphabet (assuming we‚Äôre only dealing with standard English letters).

So yeah, overall it‚Äôs a pretty neat and efficient solution!

Conclusion

And there you have it, folks. I just walked you through my thought process and solution for LeetCode problem 383. If you‚Äôre diving into the world of algorithms and data structures, it‚Äôs super important to keep practicing, and I‚Äôm here to document my grind.

Feel free to hit me up with your own solutions or questions in the comments. Let‚Äôs keep this programming journey rolling!

References

  • LeetCode Problem 383
entry.summary: In this post, I'll walk you through my daily grind of solving LeetCode problems, focusing on problem 383: Ransom Note. Get ready for some code!

entry.title: Solving LeetCode Problem 876: Middle of the Linked List

link.title: Solving LeetCode Problem 876: Middle of the Linked List

entry.content:
The Question

The problem states:

Given the head of a singly linked list, return the middle node of the linked list. If there are two middle nodes, return the second middle node.

So, if you have a linked list like this:
1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5
Your answer should be the node with value 3 since it‚Äôs the middle. But if you had 1 -> 2 -> 3 -> 4 -> 5 -> 6, you should return the node with value 4 because there‚Äôs a tie!

My Solution

Alright, let‚Äôs get to the juicy part‚Äîhere‚Äôs how I solved this problem. The classic approach here uses a two-pointer technique: a slow pointer and a fast pointer. The fast pointer moves twice as fast as the slow one. When the fast pointer reaches the end of the list, the slow pointer will be at the middle. Here‚Äôs the code:

/** 
 * Definition for singly-linked list. 
 */
public class ListNode {
    int val;
    ListNode next;
    ListNode() {}
    ListNode(int val) {
        this.val = val;
    }
    ListNode(int val, ListNode next) {
        this.val = val;
        this.next = next;
    }
}

class Solution {
    public ListNode middleNode(ListNode head) {
        ListNode slowPointer = head;
        ListNode fastPointer = head;
        
        // Move fast pointer 2 nodes and slow pointer 1 node at a time
        while (fastPointer != null && fastPointer.next != null) {
            fastPointer = fastPointer.next.next;
            slowPointer = slowPointer.next;
        }
        return slowPointer; // When fastPointer reaches the end, slowPointer is at the middle
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

Now, let‚Äôs break down the complexities, shall we?

  • Time Complexity: O(n) ‚Äì We need to traverse the list just once to find the middle node. Simple enough, right?
  • Space Complexity: O(1) ‚Äì We‚Äôre not using any extra space here apart from a couple of pointers, which is pretty damn efficient.

References:

  • LeetCode Problem 876
  • Two-pointer Technique Overview

Catch you later! Happy coding!
entry.summary: In this article, I'm diving into LeetCode Problem 876, where I'll walk you through my solution to finding the middle of a linked list. Strap in for some laid-back coding insights!

entry.title: LeetCode Question 1342: Number of Steps to Reduce a Number to Zero - My Simple Solution

link.title: LeetCode Question 1342: Number of Steps to Reduce a Number to Zero - My Simple Solution

entry.content:
Let‚Äôs kick things off with the problem statement. The challenge is to find out how many steps it takes to reduce a number to zero, where the steps are defined as follows:

  • If the number is even, divide it by 2.
  • If it‚Äôs odd, subtract 1 from it.

Sounds straightforward, right? Like, how hard can it be to reduce an integer to zero with just those two operations? Well, let‚Äôs throw some Java code into the mix to show you how it‚Äôs done!

My Java Solution

Here‚Äôs the code I came up with:

class Solution {
    public int numberOfSteps(int num) {
        int i = 0; // This will count our steps
        while (num > 0) {
            i++; // Increment step count
            if (num % 2 == 0) {
                num = num / 2; // Even, so divide
            } else {
                num = num - 1; // Odd, so subtract
            }
        }
        return i; // Return total steps taken
    }
}

A Quick Example

Let‚Äôs see this in action with an example.

Say the input is num = 14. Here‚Äôs how the steps would play out:

  • Start with 14 (even) ‚Üí divide by 2 ‚Üí 7
  • 7 (odd) ‚Üí subtract 1 ‚Üí 6
  • 6 (even) ‚Üí divide by 2 ‚Üí 3
  • 3 (odd) ‚Üí subtract 1 ‚Üí 2
  • 2 (even) ‚Üí divide by 2 ‚Üí 1
  • 1 (odd) ‚Üí subtract 1 ‚Üí 0

So, the total steps would be 6.

Performance and Complexity

In terms of performance:

  • Time Complexity: O(log n) ‚Äî This is because every time you divide by 2, you effectively halve the number of operations needed.
  • Space Complexity: O(1) ‚Äî We‚Äôre only using a fixed amount of space (the variable i).

References

  • LeetCode Problem 1342
  • Java Documentation
    Happy coding!
entry.summary: In this post, I‚Äôll walk you through my solution for LeetCode problem 1342‚Äîhow to reduce a number to zero step by step. Let‚Äôs dive into the code and break it down!

entry.title: Leetcode Question 412: Fizz Buzz - My Simple Solution

link.title: Leetcode Question 412: Fizz Buzz - My Simple Solution

entry.content:
The Fizz Buzz Problem

Here‚Äôs the deal: you get a number n, and your task is to print an array with the numbers from 1 to n, but instead of multiples of 3, you do ‚ÄúFizz‚Äù, multiples of 5 become ‚ÄúBuzz‚Äù, and for numbers that are multiples of both 3 and 5, you print ‚ÄúFizzBuzz‚Äù. Pretty straightforward, right? Let‚Äôs break it down.

Here‚Äôs the full problem statement if you want to check it out:

  • Write a program that outputs the string representation of numbers from 1 to n.
  • But for multiples of three it should output ‚ÄúFizz‚Äù instead of the number.
  • For the multiples of five output ‚ÄúBuzz‚Äù.
  • For numbers which are multiples of both three and five output ‚ÄúFizzBuzz‚Äù.

My Fizz Buzz Solution

Here‚Äôs how I whipped this up in Java:

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

class Solution {
    public List<String> fizzBuzz(int n) {
        List<String> answer = new ArrayList<>();
        for(int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
            String ans = "";
            if(i % 3 == 0) ans += "Fizz";
            if(i % 5 == 0) ans += "Buzz";
            if(ans.isEmpty()) ans = String.valueOf(i);
            answer.add(ans);
        }
        return answer;
    }
}

Complexity Analysis

Now, let‚Äôs chat about performance because, let‚Äôs face it, nobody likes shit code that runs like a snail.

  • Time Complexity: This bad boy runs in O(n) time because we‚Äôre looping through numbers from 1 to n. Each iteration checks conditions and does basic string operations, so there are no hidden surprises here.

  • Space Complexity: The space complexity is O(n) as well because we‚Äôre storing up to n strings in our list. That‚Äôs pretty standard for problems that require returning collections.

References:

  • Leetcode Problem 412: Fizz Buzz
  • Java Documentation

And that‚Äôs a wrap, folks! Happy coding, and remember: keep it funky.
entry.summary: In this post, I‚Äôm sharing my resolution to Leetcode‚Äôs Fizz Buzz problem. It‚Äôs simple yet useful, so let's dive in together!

entry.title: LeetCode Problem 1672: Solving the Richest Customer Wealth Challenge

link.title: LeetCode Problem 1672: Solving the Richest Customer Wealth Challenge

entry.content:
The Problem

You‚Äôre given a 2D array accounts, where each row represents a customer, and each column represents the amount of money they have in different banks. Your job is to find out which customer is the richest. In other words, you need to find out the maximum wealth among all customers.

Visualize it like this:

accounts = [[1, 2, 3],
            [3, 2, 1],
            [4, 5, 6]]

Here, the first customer has wealth of 6, the second has 6 as well, and the third has 15. So the answer is 15.

The Solution

Here‚Äôs how I went about solving this thing in Java. I mean, it‚Äôs pretty basic but hey, it works like a charm! Here‚Äôs the code:

class Solution {
    public int maximumWealth(int[][] accounts) {
        int richKid = 0;  // Store the wealth of the richest customer
        for (int i = 0; i < accounts.length; i++) {  // Loop through each customer
            int custWealth = 0;  // Reset customer's wealth for each customer
            for (int j = 0; j < accounts[0].length; j++) {  // Loop through each bank account
                custWealth += accounts[i][j];  // Add the wealth for this customer
            }
            // Update richKid if current customer's wealth is greater
            richKid = Math.max(richKid, custWealth);
        }
        return richKid;  // Return the maximum wealth found
    }
}

Complexity

  • Time Complexity: O(m * n), where m is the number of customers and n is the number of banks. Clearly, we‚Äôre checking every account for every customer.
  • Space Complexity: O(1), since we‚Äôre using only a few additional variables for calculations.

References

  • LeetCode Problem 1672
  • Java Documentation
entry.summary: Dive into my journey of tackling LeetCode problem 1672, where I dissect the simplest way to find the richest customer in a matrix of accounts. Grab a coffee and let's code!
